bibl.title: Letter from Juan Guiteras to the Surgeon General, May 18, 1910

div1.p: Guiteras informs the Surgeon General that they have seemingly overlooked the work of Taylor when listing those involved with the yellow fever investigation, and urges him to have Taylor's name included.

div1.head: Letter from Juan Guiteras to the Surgeon General, May 18, 1910
div1.opener:
Dirección de Sanidad
-----
Particular
Taylor
May 18th, 1910.-
To the Surgeon General
U. S. Army.
Dear Sir:-
div1.p:
Reading your letter to the Hon. Robert L.
Owen I have been struck by the injustice we have all
done Mr. John R. Taylor in the matter of credit due for
submission to experiments in the demonstration of the
etiology of yellow fever.

In your letter his name appears with number 5,
under the additional experiments by Major Gorgas and
myself, page 7, as an Englishman. Mr. Taylor had been
at the time of the experiments for many years an Ameri-
can citizen, though born in England. He had been my la-
boratory assistant in the University of Pennsylvania.

No one submitted more frequently than himself
to the bite of infected mosquitos. His devotion to duty,
his enthusiasm were greatly instrumental in inducing
others to submit to the experiments. He had charge of
the care of the mosquitos in my laboratory, and he has
since continued to do good work in the study of these
insects.

So much as a matter of course, without regard to
retribution, and without pretentions of any kind did he
go through the series of experiments and his attack of

experimental yellow fever that I had partly overlooked
the debt we owe to him.

I hope his name will be included in the list of
Americans who contributed to this great achievement.

Both Col. Gorgas and Col. Kean will, I am
sure, support these statements.
